reviewText: The performance in HOLLYWOOD REVUE of 1929 of Nacio Herb Brown's "Singin' in the Rain" inspired the title sequence of the 1952 musical with Gene Kelly, Debbie Reynolds and Donald O'Connor. This is the film that alledgedly sank John Gilbert, for studio head Louis B. Mayer, who was intent on destroying Gilbert's career after the actor sucker punched him, started a rumor that he had a squeaky speaking voice. The manufactured Gilbert fiasco is another element ofSINGIN' IN THE RAIN, where star Lina Lamont has a laughably bad speaking voice.These variety entertainments were popular in the first years of sound film; a surprising number were in part or wholly in color. Most are now "lost," for when the format ran its course in the mid '30s, studios rashly dustbinned the copies and masters, thinking them worthless.Featured are the singing and dancing talents of such actresses as Joan Crawford and Marie Dressler, also Master of Ceremonies Jack Benny (in his movie debut), Cliff Edwards, aka Ukulele Ike, later the voice of Disney's Jiminy Cricket, Charles King, Gus Edwards, Norma Shearer (Irving Thalberg's wife), Marion Davies (WR Hearst's mistress), Laurel & Hardy, who do a great magician act (note: Stan never talks!), Buster Keaton in drag as a princess of the undersea kingdom, Bessie Love, Polly Moran, Lionel Barrymore, the Brox Sisters, Conrad Nagel, Anita Page, a huge chorus line and the MGM studio orchestra.Uncrediteds include Lionel Barrymore, songwriter Nacio Herb Brown and Ann Dvorak.Conspicuously missing are Greta Garbo, Lon Chaney and Ramon Novarro. (Garbo decidedANNA CHRISTIEwould be her "talkie" debut.)
summary: Emcee: "Now, I believe that most of you are unfamiliar with the adagio. I know I am... and so are the dancers."

reviewText: Info from IMDB: "Some sources list the original running time of "Hollywood Revue of 1929" as 130 minutes. At least two sequences in the original roadshow version are missing from current prints: an opening recitation by the showgirls who are seen posing in the "Hollywood Revue" sign after the opening credits, and the appearance of Nils Asther, who assisted Jack Benny in introducing the final "Orange Blossom" number.2"This Version has a lenght of 116 min and its very entertaining. It's not a movie with a story. Its a revue show with 25 stars from silent movie era like: William Haines, Marie Dressler (her "I'm the Queen" its very entertaining), Ukelele Ike, Jack Benny (his first on screen appearance), Anita Page, Joan Crawford, and any more, including a chorus girl named Carla Laemmle (who had the first speaking words in a fantasy/horror movie: "Dracula" in 1931 and who's still living and making at age of 101 a new movie "The Extra"), Buster Keaton, Polly MoranACT I- The Palace of Minstrel sung and danced by a minstrel chorus- Masters of Ceremonies Jack Benny introduces Conrad Nagel. Cliff Edwards interferes.- Got a Feeling for You sung by Joan Crawford- "Old Folks at Home" sung by chorus- Old Black Joe sung by chorus- Low-Down Rhythm sung and danced by June Purcell- Your Mother and Mine sung by Charles King- You Were Meant for Me "sung" by Conrad Nagel (whose voice was dubbed by Charles King) to Anita Page- Nobody but You sung by Cliff Edwards- Your Mother and Mine played by Jack Benny on his violin with interjections from Karl Dane and George K. Arthur- Cut Up comedy skit featuring William Haines ripping up Jack Benny's suit- I Never Knew I Could Do a Thing Like That sung by Bessie Love- For I'm the Queen sung by Marie Dressler, assisted by Polly Moran- Magic Act introduced by Jack Benny, featuring Laurel and Hardy as magicians in a comedy skit (their first appearance in a sound feature film)-Military March with Marion Davies singing "Oh, What a Man" and "Tommy Atkins on Parade" followed by military drill and dancing. The Brox Sisters conclude this number singing "Strike Up the Band"IntermissionIntermission - "Nobody But You", "Your Mother and Mine" and "I've Got A Feeling for You" - OrchestraACT II- The Pearl Ballet sung by James Burrows, danced by Beth Laemmle and the Albertina Rasch ballet- The Dance of the Sea, an "underwater" dance performed by Buster Keaton- Lon Chaney's Gonna Get You If You Don't Watch Out sung by Gus Edwards- The Adagio Dance with the Natova Company- Romeo and Juliet (in Technicolor) with John Gilbert and Norma Shearer, with Lionel Barrymore as director- Singin' in the Rain introduced by Cliff Edwards, with The Brox Sisters- Charlie, Gus, and Ike with Charles King, Gus Edwards, and Cliff Edwards- Marie, Polly, and Bess with Marie Dressler, Polly Moran, and Bessie Love- Orange Blossom Time (in two-strip Technicolor), sung by Charles King to Myrtle McLaughlin, danced by the  Albertina Rasch Ballet- Singin' in the Rain (finale) (in two-strip Technicolor), sung by entire castThe DVDThe Picture quality is pretty good for NOT remastered or restored.A Minus: has no subtitlesFazit: its entertaining!!!

reviewText: Every major studio did an all-talking revue in the years 1929 and 1930. However, MGM was the first with their "Hollywood Revue of 1929". The purpose of this film was to prove that the studio had the talent to succeed in talking pictures with their stable of stars. Since MGM marketed their stars as their chief assets more than any other studio, this revue came off the best, and it made lots of money at the box office, prompting a stampede by the other studios to produce similar films.This film has no plot. It is simply a variety show put on by the MGM stars of 1929. You'll see many that you recognize, such as emcee Jack Benny, and some that you've probably never heard of unless you're a fan of 20's and early 30's films, such as Charles King and Karl Dane. Many interesting things go on such as Ann Dvorak slapping Jack Benny, William Haines eating Jack Benny's suit, Laurel and Hardy in a magic act, Joan Crawford being introduced for a dance number as the "personification of youth and beauty and joy and happiness", and Buster Keaton dressed in drag and doing an exotic dance. However, the middle section sags dreadfully and gives us some hint of what killed vaudeville with an adagio troupe act that seems to go on forever. Lon Chaney has a number dedicated to him, but he does not appear. Cliff Edwards and the Brox Sisters perform "Singin in the Rain" and then the whole cast assembles at the end of the film to reprise the song with Noah's Ark behind them - a probable dig at Jack Warner by Louis B. for the Warner film by the same name. The camera pans over each star slowly, emphasizing what is important to this studio at this time - its star power.I've rated this film 5/5, but you must remember that I find this film impossible to rate in a general sense. As entertainment for the average 21st century moviegoer it fails miserably, but as a snapshot of the MGM lot and the hopes and dreams of their stars entering the talkie era it is priceless. As an early talkie fan or film history buff this film is worth five stars.The video and audio are pretty good and well preserved, though no restoration has been done for this particular release. Additionally, the original Technicolor sequences are intact and included. Also note that this DVD-R product is available directly from Warner Brothers for under twenty dollars.
summary: The best of the all talking revues of 1929-1930

reviewText: This is a curious movie that, if nothing else, is a fascinating historical record. It is a revue which sort of beckons back to the days of what I imagine vaudeville might have been like. Singing, dancing, comedy sketches, but no contortionists or jugglers. There are plenty of sight gags, however.Just my opinion, but I think this movie might never have happened if film had stayed silent.  It reflects the need of an industry that is in a state of flux that needs to come up with the next great thing to stay alive and viable. From the outset it is amply apparent that MGM took its stable of stars ("more stars than there are in heaven") and gave its cooperative contractees parts in this allstar jamboree regardless if they were actually suited for these rolls or not.The casting represents a fairly comprehensive roster of celebrities. MC'd by Jack Benny and leading man Conrad Nagel, MGM luminaries included are Joan Crawford, Cliff Edwards (aka Ukelele Ike and later on down the pike the voice of Disney's Jiminy Cricket), Norma Shearer, John Gilbert, Karl Dane, George K. Arthur, Gus Edwards, Charles King, Gwen Lee, Anita Page, Bessie Love, Laurel & Hardy, Lionel Barrymore, Buster Keaton, Marie Dressler and her comedy sidekick Polly Moran. As backup there are novelty acts such as the Albertina Rausch dancers, and the Italian Quartet. It's interesting to note that most of the cast were either dead or out of the movie business with the major exceptions being Crawford, Shearer, Benny, and Barrymore. By 1935, MGM was populated with a radically different cast of stars, many of whom sang and danced.I'd like to say that all the performances were good, but some were absolutely strange. Joan Crawford's dancing is o.k., but her singing isn't anything to brag about. While she initially starts singing, she makes no pretense of moving her lips as she dances her heart out while her singing soundtrack drones on. She stops dancing, relaxes for a minute and then starts moving her lips in an awkward effort to synchronize her moving lips to the music. There are also those strange moments when a stationary camera goes out of focus momentarily. Initially, I wasn't sure if it was me or the picture. However, it kept happening enough to seem sort of funny.When all of this was going on, I kept wondering if the odd camera work as well as minor glitches with the sound were the result of technology yet to be perfected. I kept going back to the movie Singing In The Rain which was heavily peppered with references to technical problems and used the transition to talking pictures as part of its plot.Regardless of the negatives cited here, I was fascinated by this film and amazed by how quickly the technology would change in a matter of 2-3 years. The "stars" in this film are remembered today mostly by old time movie buffs. Realistically, many failed to make the grade and would soon leave the movie industry. As a finished product, this movie utilizes special effects and even a two strip color finale that was guaranteed to get the audiences attention. What might seem less than perfect today undoubtedly transfixed a 1929 audience hungry to see their favorite stars talk, sing, dance and offer up some comedy shtick.This movie has not been remastered or cleaned up. There are no special features. What you see is what you get. What is cool about it is that it is finally available on DVD. It isn't shown often. I had an old VHS tape that I recorded from a rare showing on commercial tv which was edited down. This is a far better copy.This is an interesting and fun movie that is fascinating to watch and has intrinsic value as a historical record.

reviewText: The Hollywood Revue of 1929 is an excellent early "talkie" film with singing and dancing performances by almost all of MGM's greatest stars at the time. True, the movie has no plot; but it wasn't made to have a plot; instead MGM used the film as a vehicle to highlight their "star power." The film is loaded with act after act after act; and the two Masters of Ceremonies Conrad Nagel (from Hollywood) and Jack Benny (from Broadway in his first film appearance) help to move the show along. Many scenes are funny; but most were intended to stun the audience and I'm sure audiences were indeed stunned to see this with sound in 1929. You can hear the slight tapping of numerous tap dancing young ladies on the stage; and there's not a single act that didn't fascinate me with the possible exception of the performance by four acrobats in the middle of the film. (The acrobat sequence drags just a bit; they could have shortened it but this is a minor quibble.)Some of the stars and their performances I'll remember for a while would be: Laurel and Hardy's comedy sequence; Williams Haines eating the (licorice) buttons of Jack Benny's coat; Charles King performing wonderfully in several numbers; Joan Crawford dancing and singing (she doesn't do either all that well but she gets by); the Romeo and Juliet Technicolor scene with Norma Shearer and John Gilbert which let audiences discover that John Gilbert's voice wasn't exactly well suited for sound (it was too high pitched); Cliff "Ukulele Ike" Edwards wanting a "nice introduction" for his act and the Technicolor scene of two lovers with dancing ballerinas who couldn't have performed any better. Of course, there's much more here; but I won't tell you much else so you can experience and enjoy it for yourself.There's a reviewer who correctly notes that by today's standards the film wouldn't exactly be the box office hit of the season; and they have a point. Nevertheless, if you are a film buff who likes early "talkies" with some of Hollywood's greatest silent film stars you can't go wrong with this one. It's a fine, mesmerizing time capsule; I recommend it for its historical import as well.
summary: Talking! Singing! Dancing! Technicolor scenes and chorus lines, too !!!

reviewText: Excellent film that details the star of U.S. varieties, a film pioneer in sound, color and variety of stars. In particular it is a curiosity for film buffs. The biggest stars of the Metro had the opportunity to get their feet wet! I loved Mary Dressler, Buster Keaton, Joan Crawford, Norma Shearer, John Gilbert .. the end of "Singing in the Rain" is extraordinary and reflects the era in which it was produced .. great!

reviewText: The Hollywood Revue of 1929(released Nov/29)stars,among others,Conrad Nagel,Jack Benny,Joan Crawford,Marion Davies,Anita Page,Marie Dressler,William Haines and Buster Keaton.This is MGM's effort at an all talking,singing and dancing film,with a bevy of its star roster on tap for the entertainment.As entertainment goes,it has its moments,but alas it doesn't hold its lustre very well after all these years.Yes,it is historically significant and we should be grateful it still is in existence,but given the year and that Hollywood's sound era was just dawning,it is a stop and start juggernaut.There are a few shining spots amongst the chaff.Cliff Edwards(Ukelele Ike)does what he does best and was sensationally talented,Joan Crawford could really sing,Marie Dressler shines in her turns(looking much healthier than she would just three short years later),Laurel and Hardy are on tap for a really funny magical act,where Stan gives Ollie the spotlight,Buster Keaton does an underwater dance for Poseidon and does a head fall and recovery that has to be seen to be believed,Jack Benny and Conrad Nagel are both good hosts,and John Gilbert and Norma Shearer are on hand in a technicolour sequence of Romeo and Juliet(disproving for all time the canard that Gilbert's voice was unsuitable for sound).In between all this are the singing and dancing numbers ad nauseum.The worst performer by far was Marion Davies who couldn't sing if her life depended on it,and her dancing was not much better.But it was hubby Hearst who was funding this picture so of course she was in no matter what.This film was shot at night to avoid scheduling problems.The problem with this particular release,unfortunately,has to do with two things A) The aspect ratio.The film is cut off at the bottom and the left side,so we end up missing quite a bit of what was originally seen.Most films you can compensate and it doesn't matter.This picture was staged on film like it actually was a live production on a theatre stage.So being able to see the full screen from one side to the other was especially important in this case.The performers and hosts would look slightly to the left or right of the camera as if looking out into the theatre audience,further giving the impression of a live performance.B)A new print of the film has got to be struck.The technicolour sequences have lost much of their colour.It is faded,scratchy  and lacklustre.They would have been something spectacular to see back in 1929,but now they look dreary and old.All in all not a great film,as film entertainment goes.It's a stop and start kind of a thing,with too much dancing and singing for dancing and singing's sake.There are a few highlights in the film and historically it is of great significance.However the film itself is in much need of repair and work.MGM dropped the ball with this release.2 1/2 - 3 stars.
summary: An early soundie,that should be in better condition
